title: Ropsten's chain split with geth 1.10.8
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `1.10.8`
OS & Version: Linux

I started a fresh geth node (Ropsten  v1.10.8), but the content is different from Etherscan from 10920274 block. 

And my geth has the latest block number of about 7,000 blocks larger. 

ref: https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/108024/how-to-handle-ropstens-chain-split-with-geth-1-10-8

regarding the `chain split`: are we safe to stay with a fresh `1.10.8` node? is the correct chain?

ref 2: https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2021/08/27/ethereum-faces-chain-split-as-node-operators-fail-to-update-geth-hotfix/
``1.10.8`` is the latest release, and will put you on the canonical chain.

Ropsten chain has been split at block height 10920274. My geth node v1.10.8 follows 0x2fd63eb95c8059a46b5afedb903ef1639b9414e9d38f70b3dfb0f733b7ced14f but [Etherscan](https://ropsten.etherscan.io/block/10920275) and Alchemy follows 0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532. Which is canonical chain?

```
Height=10920275
Alchemy=0x06533bf198874719a3de36317181459ad99a139d7a8555d4f209cc07fcf86483
Local=0x5b6007e7e4d44c0ff8df036c01c42bf2c15313fbd95cfa4c403bbc6051077e39

Height=10920274
Alchemy=0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532
Local=0x2fd63eb95c8059a46b5afedb903ef1639b9414e9d38f70b3dfb0f733b7ced14f

Height=10920273
Alchemy=0x1a481511d4b8e7a2ab55e5e03eabc81be7ccda47763da9ab18414074ae678355
Local=0x1a481511d4b8e7a2ab55e5e03eabc81be7ccda47763da9ab18414074ae678355
```

I am currently seeing similar issues with Ropsten nodes, but not the same block you are.  I am seeing this on one node where it is reporting ~10951638 as the highest block and that it is not syncing, and also has txs in those blocks:
Node A
```

false
> eth.blockNumber
10951368

"0xd31a3f5ad53a71abbaa4558c7fb5d6ca857cf55c61947d6473f42fe2ddf154ce", "0x31db97a1b4a47465cd0255b803a1cda85e1af6c3ac0a850803e0a0aac6305e86", "0x4ff6dfd0e261faff6b13cc433c2eb2bd6b1895b3dcddaee519fe4f7ef4eabe4f", "0xb4a56aa139c1d20135d3c37c8912f4e64b07fa4777456ea8ebaabecdb4ebd4f5", "0x3420cd5bc165b2786fbe885de06cecb7c927a81180e41de1cd392da276936880", "0xef1ee053b0cc0e9e545e6399738157b08aa6eb75474b9fc2eeb3b6323ed1d231"],
  transactionsRoot: "0x0d156a1eb1ea9102112a4fd9e992e421eb3880a67bed7bafe3b7195da72a92d6",
  uncles: []
}
```
while on other nodes, and Etherscan, I am seeing the following for `eth.syncing` on the local console
Node B
```
> eth.syncing
{
  currentBlock: 10949394,
  highestBlock: 10951357,
  knownStates: 0,
  pulledStates: 0,
  startingBlock: 10920273
}
``` 
There are differences between hashes of blocks that are available on both of these nodes too.
`eth.getBlock('10949394')`
Node A: `0x9e7a11a8cf8f1fa1eccfe7b80d6d0fad26159f82cb125673e63fc2b5ca1d5ba1`
Node B: `hash: "0x9e7a11a8cf8f1fa1eccfe7b80d6d0fad26159f82cb125673e63fc2b5ca1d5ba1",`

I have tried to do a `debug.setHead()` on these nodes but they always seem to come back to being on this weird fork.  Not sure if this is an issue with Geth or just the Ropsten chain itself.  Can provide any additional details from nodes if needed.

I would follow etherscan, so you would need to add
`--whitelist 10920274=0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532` when starting geth and then run `debug.setHead('0xA6A14E')` in the console

@MariusVanDerWijden Do you know if etherscan has updated its node to the latest `1.10.8` version? 
Does somebody know why this happened?

Should we follow majority?

| #10920274               | Hash                                                               |
|-------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Alchemy                 | 0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532 |
| [Anyblock Analytics](https://explorer.anyblock.tools/ethereum/ethereum/ropsten/block/10920274/) | 0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532 |
| [bitaps.com](https://teth.bitaps.com/10920274) | 0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532 |
| [Etherscan](https://ropsten.etherscan.io/block/10920274)               | 0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532 |
| Infura                  | 0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532 |
| QuickNode (shared node) | 0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532 |
| Local (v1.10.8)                  | 0x2fd63eb95c8059a46b5afedb903ef1639b9414e9d38f70b3dfb0f733b7ced14f |
I'm hoping more people set their `--whitelist` option for this, have a node with it set and its only connecting to 3 peers max.

I think the nodes have figured it out?  I am seeing behavior like this one multiple nodes at the moment.  
**Archival Node:** 
```
DEBUG[09-03|02:32:06.292] Inserted forked block                    number=10,909,230 hash=18e44b..3239e9 diff=1,315,110,4 │

│ DEBUG[09-03|02:32:06.312] Dereferenced trie from memory database   nodes=141     size=41.20KiB  time="451.286µs"  gcnodes │
```
**Full Node**
```
│ DEBUG[09-03|02:28:14.663] Fetching batch of block bodies           id=ac9aa77a177a7cfc conn=inbound            count=128
DEBUG[09-03|02:28:14.662] Fetching batch of block bodies           id=f097674ecb7541d0 conn=inbound            count=128                  ││ DEBUG[09-03|02:28:14.663] Fetching batch of block bodies           id=ac9aa77a177a7cfc conn=inbound            count=128                  ││ DEBUG[09-03|02:28:14.664] Fetching batch of block bodies           id=9339a0a38c5e07a2 conn=inbound            count=128                  │
```

Somewhat related, when the good chain stops getting mined (which seems to be the case right now), our ropsten nodes respond to `eth_syncing` with a result like this:

```
{
  currentBlock: 10996911,
  highestBlock: 10997054,
  knownStates: 276556778,
  pulledStates: 276556778,
  startingBlock: 10933392
}
```

I think this is because `highestBlock` is calculated from all peers, even ones that are on the wrong chain.
Can anyone provide a enode that has correct chain as ropsten.etherscan please?

> I would follow etherscan, so you would need to add
> `--whitelist 10920274=0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532` when starting geth and then run `debug.setHead('0xA6A14E')` in the console

Thanks, ropsten and ethScan synchronization are highly consistent after I do this.

> Can anyone provide a enode that has correct chain as ropsten.etherscan please?

I recommend you to add whitelist and use json rpc "debug_setHead" to let your eth fullnode to find correct peers automatically.

> I would follow etherscan, so you would need to add
> `--whitelist 10920274=0xfd652086d220d506ae5b7cb80fde97d2f3f7028d346cc7d9d384a83d3d638532` when starting geth and then run `debug.setHead('0xA6A14E')` in the console

thanks for this solution again
